newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission, USDA continue grain subsidy, biotech talks.
newsitem.headline: Commission, USDA continue grain subsidy, biotech talks.

text.p: European Commission and U.S. agricultural officials pursued technical talks on Wednesday on grain subsidies, genetically modified maize and other farm issues with neither side disclosing details.
"Intensive talks were held yesterday afternoon," a Commission agricultural official said.
A U.S. official said there were no current plans for a press briefing.
Commission Director General for Agriculture, Guy Legras, discussed a wide range of issues with Paul Drazek, senior trade adviser to U.S. Agriculture Secretary, Dan Glickman.
The Commission official gave no details, saying discussions were continuing at a lower level.

The U.S. is concerned that the EU's resumption last month of wheat export subsidies could start a slide towards a renewed grain subsidy war as world prices continue to fall under the pressure of much bigger harvests this year.
The U.S. has warned that it will fight subsidies with subsidies if necessary.
Washington is also pressing Brussels to speed up approval of genetically-modified maize before the U.S. crop is harvested.

The maize, produced by the Swiss company Ciba-Geigy and resistant to the corn borer pest, has been attacked by European environmental and consumer groups and referred to EU scientific committees on foodstuffs, pesticides and animal nutrition.

The committees are not expected to give their advice until December, a Commission environment official said, adding that other genetically-modified maize and soybean varieties still had to be examined.
The EU earlier this year approved the use of Monsanto's Roundup Ready herebicide resistant soybeans.
Glickman has said the biotech maize was safe and that European objections were based on "unsound science." He warned that maize could become a transatlantic trade issue.
U.S. officials have said that demands for special labelling were impractical given the huge volume of exported maize.
U.S. maize exports to the EU were worth $530 million in 1995/96 (July/June) when prices were exceptionally high.
Industry sources say tests exist for identifying modified and unmodified maize and soybeans but these would result in extra costs.
